Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Hello, Amy.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Hi, Darryl.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Amy, would you please tell the kids you'll be right back, and then shut the door and come outside to talk to us for a minute?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: OK.  Be right back, you guys!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You're not supposed to go out, Amy.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: She's going to smoke a cigarette.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy, come on! I'm really late!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: How was school?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Stupid.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Why do you say that?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: We're supposed to write a story for English homework, but they didn't tell us what it's supposed to be about.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I mean they didn't tell us what it's supposed to be about. They said do whatever you want.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: So what's wrong with that?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Nothing. I just think it's unstructured.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I'm sure you'll be able to think of something. If you can't, I'll help you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Don't forget your backpack.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It's not a backpack, it's a knapsack.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Don't forget your knapsack.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Give me a kiss.

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: Guess who's been asking for you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh no, really?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, come in!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Mr. Everett?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah: Brian.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian. Hi. I'm Samantha Prescott -- I'm the lending officer?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, hi, how are you? Come on in. Sit down.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I am so sorry I was late...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, we missed you before...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I got held up. Believe me, it is not something I make a habit of...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm sure it's not. Actually -- could you just, could you close that door for me? Thanks.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- so I always just run out at 3:15 to pick him up and then run him real quick over to the sitter's house. Anyway, Larry never minded about it and I was just hoping it would be OK with you too...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well -- Samantha -- I realize that Scottsville is not exactly a major banking center...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No it's not...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No -- I know it's not... But it's kind of a personal challenge to me to see what we can do to bring local service up to the same kinds of standards we'd be trying to meet if we were the biggest branch in the state. And that means I don't want anybody running out at 3:15 or 3:30, or whenever the bus happens to come in that day. Now is there anybody else who can pick your son up after school? Does your husband work in the area? Do you --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh -- No -- Rudy Sr. isn't "on the scene." So to speak.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, I can give you a couple of days to make some other arrangement, but...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- Brian? I understand what you're saying, and I think it's great. I do. Because there's a lot of things around here that could use some attention. Believe me. But I've honestly been meeting that bus every day for four years now and it really does take just fifteen minutes, and if I take the time out of my lunch hour...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'd really prefer it if you would make some other arrangement. OK?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'll do my best...!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: How old's your son?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: He's eight.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's a terrific age.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: You got a letter from Uncle Terry.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Whose room is he gonna stay in?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: He can stay in the little room.  But you know what? He's not going to live here. He's only gonna stay for a little while... And it's OK if you don't remember him, because you were only six the last time he was here... But it'll be nice if you got a chance to get to know each other a little bit. Don't you think?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy? Would it distract you if I put on some music?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Did you think of a story?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Uh huh.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What's it about?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: My father.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What about your father?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It's just a made-up story about him.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Can I read it when you're done?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It's not very good.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Don't say that.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Anyway, Bob, it's sort of this adventure story, and Rudy's father is this secret agent or something, working for the government... And it just made me feel weird. You know? Because I never really say much to him about Rudy Sr., because I don't know what to say. And I don't know whether I should just let him imagine whatever he wants to imagine, or whether I should sit him down sometime and tell him, you know, that his father is not such a nice person. You know?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Well... I don't know, Sammy. What have you told him already?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Not much. He knows I don't have the highest opinion of him. And he knows I don't want to see him or know anything about him, ever. But I tried to keep it kind of neutral. Anyway... I could go into a lot more detail, believe me.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Well... It's an interesting problem. But I don't really know what to tell you... It's a little outside my personal field of expertise...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I'd be glad to give it some thought...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Nothing... I'm just glad to see you... I'm glad you called me.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I bet you were surprised...!

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Um -- a little.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I should get going...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yeah... I've got the baby-sitter... But... Thanks for a lovely evening.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Oh. Thank you.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Hey, Terry.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Where'd you get the hat?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Oh, I got it on the street for a dollar.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: It's nice.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, you know, it's pretty much your standard woolen hat.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Yeah, I had a very similar reaction to it.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Can I get that money from you?

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Yeah. Sorry.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Is that all you have?

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Can you borrow some cash from your brother?

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Um, yeah, but that would involve speaking to him.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, I'm definitely gonna be gone for a couple of days at least, Sheila.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Why do you have to stay so long?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Because my sister is not a bank, you know? I can't just show up and ask her for --

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: You seem to think my brother's a bank!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Oh Sheila can we just cut out the puerile crap?! I'll be back just as soon as I can. OK? I am not the kind of man that everyone says I am.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: I know you're not.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'll call you tonight.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Don't you wanna tell me you love me?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I love you.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: That was really convincing.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... I think after this is over you should seriously consider moving back home.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Oh, yeah.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: All right...

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: You gonna call tonight?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Definitely.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hello?... TERRY!...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Whoa there!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: God damn! Terry Prescott! How you doin'? Gimme a cuddle!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: How you doin', Darryl?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Which way you headed?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm just goin' to see Sammy at Dawson's...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Can I walk with you a little?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sure, yeah --

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: So Sammy says you been out in Alaska...?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I was workin' out there for a little while...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: -- Sammy says she's gettin' postcards from all across the country.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I've been all over the place...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, it's good to have you back here, I'll tell you that.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Thanks, Darryl. Keep enforcing the peace.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, that'll be a little harder now that you're home, but I'll do what I can.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No, man, I'm reformed.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. Good to see you, kid.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Thanks, Darryl.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sorry about yesterday --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I don't care --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I was studying the bus description... and I just... I got on the wrong bus -- I mean I missed my stop --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I don't care, Terry. I'm just so glad to see you...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm glad to see you too, Sammy. Um... are you coming from work?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Um, no, it's Saturday...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, no, it's just... you're dressed so formally...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh. No. You know, I just thought I'd -- You know I thought it was a special occasion... which it is...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No, it's good. I thought I'd dress up too.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That's OK. You look fine.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, this is the haute cuisine of garments.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Nothing, nothing... Um... So how are you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm fine.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: How's Rudy?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: We're fine, Terry. How are you?  I mean --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- Where have you been lately, Terry?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: -- I know, I haven't been --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I got a postcard from you from Alaska...?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I was up there for a while...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: But that was in the Fall, Terry...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I know I've been out of touch...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I was a little worried.  I mean --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Oh, I been a lotta different places... Um... I went down to Florida for a while... I was doing some work in Orlando... I've been all over the place.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well... I just wish you would have let me know you were OK...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah. I didn't realize it'd been so long...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Are you gonna stay in town for a while?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, I don't know... I got all these things I gotta do back in Worcester...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: ...Yeah, so I'm probably not gonna be able to stay more than a day or so...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh... Well... That's all right...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: ...I'm kind of trying to keep to a schedule of sorts. It's a long and worthy story but I won't trouble you with it right now.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Are you expecting someone?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Who would I be expecting here?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You just keep looking around, that's all.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No, I was just wondering if we could get some more refreshments, actually.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I've actually got to confess to you, Sammy... that the reason you may not have heard from me for a little while is that I've been kind of unable to write... on account of the fact that I was in jail for a little while.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You were what?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, I did a little time, I guess, in Florida. For, uh, just for bullshit...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: It was just bullshit...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What did you do?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I didn't do anything. Does it occur to you that maybe I was wronged?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, could I please --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh my God! --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Would you please let me --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- What happened?!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I got into a fight in a bar down in Florida. Which I was not the one who instigated it, at all. But they worked up all this bullshit against me and they threw me in the pen for three months. I didn't write you because I didn't want you to get all upset about it. I just figured you'd figure I was on the road for a little while. I know it was stupid and I'm sorry. I really didn't mean to make you worry. But you know what? I can't run around all the time doin' stuff or not doin' stuff because it's gonna make you worry! Because then I come back here, and I tell you about my fuckin'... traumas, and I get this wounded little "I've Let You Down" bullshit, over and over again, and it really just -- cramps me! Like I just want to get out from under it!... And here I am back in this fuckin' hole explaining myself to you again!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: OK -- Can you please stop cursing at me?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I mean, I realize I'm in no position to, uh, basically say anything, ever -- But it's not like I'm down there in some redneck bar in Florida having an argument with some stripper's boyfriend and I suddenly think, "Hey! Maybe this'd be a good time to really stick it to Sammy and get myself locked up for a few months."

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Me too, man. I mean "welcome home."

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hey -- You don't write me for six months, I have no idea where you are --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm sorry --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- I don't know if you're alive or dead --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm sorry --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- and then you show up out of nowhere and tell me you were in jail?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry, Sammy, I'm really sorry...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sammy...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um... I'm in the midst of a slight predicament...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What do you need? Money?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um... Yeah... I'm broke. I gotta get back to Worcester tomorrow. I got this girl there, and she's kind of in a bad situation...? I just need to borrow some money. Whatever you can spare.  I'll pay you back... I'll pay you back, man.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I really wish Mom was here.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: So do I, man.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Nobody knows what to do with you.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I know how they feel, man.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Terry? Can I ask you something?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- I mean, do you ever go to church anymore?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Come on, Sammy, can we not talk about that shit?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um -- No, Sammy. I don't.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Can you tell me why not?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um, yeah. Because I think it's ridiculous.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- can you tell me without like, denigrating what I believe in?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Because I think it's primitive, OK? I think it's a fairy tale.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- I mean, have you ever considered that maybe that's part of what's making things so difficult for you?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- That you've lost hold of -- well, not just your religious feeling, but lost hold of any kind of anchor, any kind of trust in anything... I mean no wonder you drift around so much. What could ever stop you? How would you ever know if you had found the right thing?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, uh, I'm not really looking for anything, man. I'm just, like, trying to get on with it.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Here we go...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Thank you, Sammy... I'm really gonna pay this back.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Where we going?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: To pick up Rudy.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... do you not even want me to visit now? 'Cause I can catch the bus at five o'clock if that's what you want.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, of course I want you to visit, you idiot! I've been looking forward to seeing you more than anything! I've been telling everyone I know that you were coming home! I cleaned the whole fucking house so it would look nice for you! I thought you were gonna stay for at least a few days! It didn't occur to me that you were just broke again. I wish you would have just sent me an invoice!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hi, is that Malcolm?... Hi, this is Terry Prescott?... I been trying to get ahold of Sheila and there's no answer, and I was just wondering if she -- She what?...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: When?... Well -- Is she all right?... Well, could I talk to her?... Well, could you give her a message that I --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: That girl I'm with tried to kill herself.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: She tried to kill herself.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Do you have everything you need?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know. Send the money I guess.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Maybe you should stay home for a little while, Terry.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, maybe that'd be a good idea.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm going to bed. Do you have everything you need?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah. Thanks.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Terry, I'm really glad you're home.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, me too, Sammy.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: OK. So we'll drop Rudy off at the bus, then all you have to do is drop me off at the bank, and just pick Rudy up at 3:30 in front of town hall, and drive him over to Carol's house. And that's it. She's on Harvey Lane, right past where the Dewitts used to live.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy knows where she lives.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: God, Mabel, don't those colors hurt your eyes?

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: Oh no, they keep me fresh.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah!  Hi, Sammy. What can I do for you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Um, Brian? Did you want us to turn this time sheet in at the end of the day, or do you want it at the end of the week...?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, end of the day'll be fine.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Seems like an awful lot of extra paperwork...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I like paperwork.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: You showed up.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Looks that way.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Put on your seat belt.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It pushes on my neck.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It pushes on my neck. It's uncomfortable.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, when somebody slams into us and you go sailin' through the windshield, that's liable to be uncomfortable too. So put on your seat belt.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Mom's parents died in a car accident.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I know. They're my parents too.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: They are?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, yeah. Your mom is my sister.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah, I know.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: So that means we have the same parents.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Oh yeah.

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: Um -- Carol just called. She said Terry and Rudy never showed up at her house?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You've got to be kidding me.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Hey, Sammy?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey. Look.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You hold it further down, you're gonna get a lot more power. You should be able to put that nail down with two or three hits. Look:

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Try it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: That's not the way I hold it.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, the way you hold it is wrong.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why can't I just do it my own way?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You can.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian? Did you want to see me?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah. I was kind of wondering what happened to you today.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh -- Didn't Mabel -- I had a false alarm about my son...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, I kind of thought you were gonna work that out.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I did work it out -- more or less --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Then why're you running outta here in the middle of the day without a word of explanation to me, Sammy?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian, don't yell at me.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm -- I'm not yelling. I'm just gettin' a little frustrated here.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well Brian:

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sorry, could you close the door please?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: ...And Eddy Dwyer lives in Buffalo, with his wife and two sons, if you can believe it.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: That is depressing.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: He just never struck me as the marrying type, that's all.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Who are you talking about?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Wild kids we used to know.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Were you a wild kid?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Not compared to your Mom.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah, right.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You don't believe me?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Ask her.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Mom, were you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No comment.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Oh -- Just readin' some of your compositions.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why are you smoking?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um... Because it's bad. Don't ever do it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I won't.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You know this used to be my room?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah...  Do you want it back?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Did you fight in Vietnam?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No. I wasn't even born yet.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Were you ever in the army?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: My father was in the army.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I know. Unfortunately he didn't fight in Vietnam either.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Were you friends with him?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Not really. We had some friends in common, I guess... I didn't like him very much.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, he wasn't very likable.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why do you say that?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know. He was always -- He always had to be better than you at everything. You know. Like if you were all playing basketball or something, everybody's havin' like a friendly game and he's like ready to kill somebody if his team didn't win. Or like if you told like a joke or a story, he always had to tell a better one? Kinda gets annoying after a while. Plus it was pretty scummy how he split on your mom and you... He was a prick. Probably still a prick. Fortunately for you though, your mom is like, the greatest. So you had some bad luck and you had some good luck.  You mind if I ask you a personal question?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Do you like it here? I mean, in Scottsville?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah...?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't know. My friends are here... I like the scenery... I don't know.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I know, I know, but it's so... There's nothing to do here.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yes there is.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No there isn't, man! It's narrow. It's dull. It's a dull, narrow town full of dull, narrow people who don't know anything except... what things are like right around here. They have no perspective whatsoever. No scope. They might as well be living in the nineteenth century because they have no idea what's going on, and if you try to tell 'em that, they wanna fuckin' kill you.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You're a good kid.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah. This doesn't apply to you directly, Sammy, but I've noticed that some of the employees have their PC monitors set with all kinds of crazy colors... Purple and polka dots or what have you. And it's not a big deal, but really, this is a bank. You know? It's not really appropriate. So I'm just asking that people stick to a more quote unquote normal range of colors in future...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Like I say, it doesn't really apply to you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No, my computer palette's pretty conservative.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Bob Steegerson.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What are you wearing?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Mom?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Do you know you have an enormous leak from the upstairs hall?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Um, yeah, thanks, I did.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Are you guys sure you're gonna be OK?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yes. Yes.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What is happening here?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: It's just -- The problem is that the pipe is corroded all the way along the length of the hall. So every time I put in a new piece it starts leaking further down.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Why don't I just call the plumber?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Why? He's not gonna do anything different than what I'm doing.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah. We're making it worse!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No we're not. Shut up.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Thank you. Thank you both.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Now, call if there's any problem, and if I'm not there, I'm either on my way or on my way back home.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: So lights out at ten... and don't spend the whole night watching TV.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Nice to meet you, Bob.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: You too.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What's your idea of the whole night?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Two hours tops.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What's your feeling about Bob?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't really know him that well.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I have bad news for you.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Great. What are we supposed to do now?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Do you know how to play pool?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I've played it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't think they let kids in there.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, we're not allowed to watch any more TV, so it's this or nothing... But if we run into any trouble, let me do the talking.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I got a hundred bucks here says me and my nephew can beat anybody in here. Only we gotta get the next game 'cause he's gotta be in bed by ten o'clock.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Just hit it nice and soft... Nice and soft.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: God damn, Rudy. I thought you said you could play.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Boys, it's all over but the cryin'.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Bob... Are you serious?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I... I don't know what to say. I --

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I mean, I know I haven't exactly been the most... decisive... guy. In the past... I don't know: I'm tired of foolin' around. And I love you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I... I'm totally... I don't know what to say.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Well, you could always say "Yes."  Or you could think about it first.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That's it: I want to think about it.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: OK... Fair enough.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Ohhhh!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: It's all yours, baby.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Just make sure to hit it really gentle. But firm. And hit it a little low so you get some backspin. Don't even hit it. Just kiss it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What do you mean, kiss it?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I mean tap it. Firm but very, very softly. And don't shoot until you know it's going in. OK?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: That was great!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: We creamed those guys! We creamed them!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Ssh...! Don't move.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: It's them!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Go! Go! Go!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Wait a minute, gimme your jacket!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I can't get my sleeve out...!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What is going on in here?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Um -- We were just out doing some star-gazing, and, uh, Rudy lost track of the time. Which I totally warned him about.  You are a bad kid.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey: I think it's OK. Just don't tell her where we went, 'cause she'll be really mad at me. OK?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I won't.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey -- I'm not kidding, Rudy.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I won't!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Did you know my Mommy used to take me and Uncle Terry out at night to look at the constellations?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Did you see that one, what's the one -- It looks like a big "W"? Cassiopeia?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Ow! Shit!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I've got a great idea. Why don't you let me call the plumber?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Do whatever you want.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh, does that make you mad?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian, get off my ass!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I didn't change the colors on your stupid computer screen.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, that's all you gotta say!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: There is nothing wrong with the work I do here. I have been doing just fine, the whole time before you came here -- And if you think that riding people in this petty, ridiculous way is the way to improve service in this bank or anywhere else I think you're out of your mind!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I didn't say there was. Could I please -- Could I please -- May I respond?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No, that's really all I have to --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: May I respond?  First of all, I don't appreciate being spoken to with that kind of language. That's not the way I talk to you, and I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't talk that way to me --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Second of all, if you say you didn't change the colors on my computer screen, then of course I accept your answer. But you and I are gonna have to find a way to work together --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: But that's not gonna happen with the attitude, it's not gonna happen with the lateness, it's not gonna happen by fighting me every step of the way -- OK, well not you, you're not late, but too much of that stuff goes on around here --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I am not late and I do not have an attitude -- Well then don't tell me I'm late if I'm not late!

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'd really like to finish!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: They were where?

Speaker: plumber
Dialogue: OK, you're all set.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: This is Chuck. Chuck, this is my wife, Nancy.

Speaker: chuck
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: Nice to meet you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: This is Mabel...

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: Nice to meet you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: This is Sammy, our lending officer. Sammy, this is my wife, Nancy.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hi. It's nice to meet you.

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: Brian -- I gotta sit down.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sure -- Let's go in my office.

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: I'm fine...!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian...?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Look, I'm glad you guys are getting along so well -- like, you have no idea -- but if I can't rely on you to remember to get him once a day...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You can!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- And what are you doing taking him to play pool in the middle of the night, and then telling him to lie to me about it?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Get out of the car.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What are we doing?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You're going to Carol's house and I'm going home.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why can't I come with you?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Because if you're such a baby you gotta tell your Mommy about us playin' pool when I totally asked you not to, and I gotta listen to her shit all day, then you're goin' to the baby-sitter's so you can stay at the baby house.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: But I didn't tell her!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You know what? Don't even fuckin' talk to me.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I didn't!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Just get out of the car.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You're working late.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: How did your wife like the bank?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Oh, fine. She wasn't feeling so great.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That's too bad.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: No -- I don't mean -- She's not ill. She's just... I don't know...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Pregnant?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's it. She's pregnant.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: It can make you kind of cranky.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Listen, I'm sorry we've been stepping on each other's toes -- I -- I'm not actually that bad a guy --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yeah, I am too... I know you're not, Brian, but you're driving everybody crazy.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, I -- I'm just trying to do my best here -- And I'm gettin' it from all sides.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I know you are...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Anyway... We'll work it out...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well... I could use a beer.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I could use a tranquilizer.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Last I heard, Rudy's Dad was living over in Auburn. But that was last year.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Must be so tough raising a kid on your own... Although I'm beginning to get the idea my wife wouldn't mind a crack at it.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh... It's just the hormones.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, no, it isn't. But never mind.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well, here's to improved employee- management relations.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Amen.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You can't judge all of Scottsville by the people in that bank, believe me.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well -- Let's -- Let's not talk about the bank.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Let's just forget about the bank for tonight.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Good idea.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Sammy?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I want you to tell me who changed the colors on my computer screen.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'll never tell.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Nowhere. I had dinner with my boss.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Kind of a late dinner, ain't it?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yeah. How was Rudy?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Did the plumber come?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yes, the fucking plumber came.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Terry -- Give me a break!!!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Nothing. I'm just tired.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You want to smoke some pot?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No I don't. Why, you got some?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: So... Bob asked me to marry him.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Wow.  Are you going to?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I don't know. If he'd've asked me this time last year I would have probably said yes. But the minute he said it, I don't know, I felt like somebody was trying to strangle me.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... bad sign.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I know.  I fucked my boss...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I know! And his wife is six months pregnant.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Jesus Christ, Sammy...!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I know, I know.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Terry, I'm sorry I got so mad before. I just don't want him, you know -- terrified of "telling," if there's --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Uh, well, that's not really his problem, Sammy.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh really? What's his problem?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: His problem is that he's like totally sheltered because you treat him like he's three, instead of eight, so that's how he behaves.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh yeah? And how do you think he should behave?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I think he shouldn't have to run and tell his Mommy every time he does something she might not like, for one thing.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Uh huh. And what do you --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I mean I took him to play pool! It was a little clandestine thing we did for fun! It wasn't like a big secret, I mean who cares? I was actually trying to be nice to him. But he's so freaked out that he disobeyed your orders that he has to fuckin' squeal on me and I have to listen to your fuckin' shit all day when I didn't even fuckin' do anything!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: First of all, he didn't tell me anything: Darryl did. OK? Second of all, I don't really give a shit if you took him to play pool: I was mad at you because you left him standing at the bus stop in the rain. But no, I don't want you telling him not to squeal, because I don't want him put in that position!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... that... is a perfect example of what I'm talking about.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You are in idiot.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Darryl told you?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, good morning. Could you get the door?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Listen -- I just --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian, that's enough.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: OK. Sorry.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: You're awfully quiet.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Um... Have you thought at all about what I said?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Of course I've been thinking about it.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: So... Any decisions? Or -- do you still want to think about it some more...?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- I mean -- I don't know, Bob. I mean, we haven't exactly been going steady the last few months, if you know what I mean --

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Yeah, no, I know --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- and then we see each other twice and you suddenly say you want to get married? I mean...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: No, you're right, you're right --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I don't know... I... Maybe this is... Last year I sort of thought you were possibly interested in that... idea... but I was the one who, you know, wasn't "ready" at that point -- So that's why I thought things kind of slowed down with us...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Don't make me feel bad for you.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I don't want you to feel bad for me.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: It's Brian.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian. Where are you?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I'm buying milk. I just thought I'd say hello.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Look, I know it's probably too late, but is there any way you can come out for a little while?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian, I think you're going crazy.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I know I am. Can you meet me?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Um, OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Um -- I have to go out for a minute. Do you want anything?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, where are you going?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I just have to go out for a little while.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, where?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I just have to go to Mabel's house.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You know what, Rudy? It's personal. This is a personal matter that has to do with Mabel. I just have to go see her for a little while.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Listen. Listen. I'm sorry I said you squealed on me. I was totally out of line, and I really owe you an apology.  Did you hear what I said?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't care.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: What's on your mind, Sammy?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, a lot. But principally... I was just wondering if you had an opinion. If you know someone, in your family, or just someone you really care about, and they just can't seem to get ahold of themselves...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You know who this is for?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Me!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: That's right, my little friend.  Hello. We're going fishing.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I got a new rod and reel, five lures, I got a hat, I got a knife and I got a fish scaler.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That's great, honey.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'll get it.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... I'm not really sure why you're here, Ron. I mean, I realize I haven't exactly been a model citizen since I got here, but compared to how things have been goin' for me lately, I thought I was doing pretty well.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: And I also find it kind of discouraging that you seem to think I need some kind of spiritual counseling or what have you, so much so that you're willing to disregard the fact that I don't believe in any of this stuff at all --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well... I didn't mean to discourage you --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I mean it's really kind of insulting.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Can I say something here?  Sammy asked me to come and talk to you, because it's her opinion that you're not gonna find what you're looking for the way you're looking for it --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: How would she know?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: But I'm really not here to try to get you to do anything, or to believe anything. And I'll tell you the same thing I told her, which is that as far as I'm concerned the only way she can help you is by her example -- by trying to be a model for you, by the way she lives her life...

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: And that doesn't mean she's supposed to be a saint, either, if that's what you're smiling about.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I didn't realize I was smiling.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: You know, Terry, a lot of people come to see me with all kinds of problems. Drugs, alcohol, marital problems, sexual problems, health problems --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Great job you got.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well... I like it. Because even in this little town, I feel like what I do is very connected with the real center of people's lives. I'm not saying I'm always Mr. Effective, but I don't feel like my life is off to the side of what's important. You know? I don't feel my happiness and comfort are based on closing my eyes to trouble within myself or trouble in other people. I don't feel like a negligible little scrap, floating around in some kind of empty void, with no sense of connectedness to anything around me except by virtue of whatever little philosophies I can scrape together on my own...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Can I ask you, Terry: Do you think your life is important?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You mean -- Like, me personally, my individual life?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... I'm not sure -- What do you mean? It's important to me. I guess. And like, to my, you know, the people who care about me...

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: But do you think it's important?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Do you think it's important in the scheme of things? Not just because it's yours, or because you're somebody's brother. Because I don't really get the impression that you do.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, I don't think... I don't particularly think anybody's life has any particular importance besides whatever -- you know -- whatever we arbitrarily give it. Which is fine. I mean we might as well... I think I'm as important as anybody else...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know: A lot of what you're saying has a real appeal to me, Ron. A lot of the stuff they told us when we were kids... But I don't want to believe something or not believe it because I might feel bad. I want to believe it because I think it's true or not... I'd like to think that my life is important... Or that it's connected to something important...

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well, isn't there any way for you to believe that without calling it God, or religion, or whatever term it is you object to?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yes. I believe that.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: So Sammy, what example will you be setting for us tonight?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What time are we getting up to go fishing?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: We're not going fishing.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I think you should go fishing with Father Ron.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't want to go fishing with Father Ron.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, I'm not takin' you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'll take you, sweetie.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I realize that you're mad at me --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm not mad at you...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- but he didn't do anything to you. And you cannot promise a little boy that you're gonna --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: ...I just, you know, after all that religious conversation, I just realized it's probably not so good for him to be spending so much time with someone like me who doesn't believe his life is important in the scheme of things --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Would you please...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm serious.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I am sure, if you put your mind to it, you can think of some other way of getting back at me besides this. So would you please just give it some thought, and take him fishing tomorrow?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I would, Sammy, I just don't think it'd be good for him.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You suck.

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Anyway... I don't know what the church's position is on adultery and fornication these days, but I felt really hypocritical not saying anything to you about it before, so... What is the official position on that stuff these days?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well... it's a sin.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Good: I think it should be.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: ...but we don't tend to focus on that aspect of it, right off the bat --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I think you should.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Maybe it was better when you came in and they screamed at you for having sex with your married boss, and were really mean to you, and told you what a terrible thing it was. Maybe it'd be better if you told me how I'm endangering my immortal soul, and if I don't quit I'm going to burn in hell. Don't you ever think that?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Um... No.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, it's a lot better than all this "Why do you think you're in this situation" psychological bullshit you hear all the time.

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: Well... Why do you think you're in this situation?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: With which one?

Speaker: ron
Dialogue: All of them.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I feel sorry for them.  Isn't that ridiculous?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I've never been so bored in my life.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah... We really shoulda been out here around seven or eight A.M.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What time is it now?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Two-thirty.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Was my father a good fisherman?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, your father was good at all that stuff. He knew everything about the woods, everything about fishing, everything about hunting and everything about cars. If he wasn't such a pain in the ass he would've been a lot of fun to be around.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Maybe he's nicer now.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I doubt it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Well, I think he is.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: How would you know? Did you ever meet him?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Were you ever curious to meet him?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, he doesn't live very far from here.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I thought he lived in Alaska.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No -- I lived in Alaska. Your dad lives in Auburn. Far as I know.  We could look him up in the phone book. Wanna try?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK -- But -- I'm sure I don't have to say this, but I'm not kidding, man: Don't -- tell -- your -- mother.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Do you want to go for a walk, or a drive? It's really nice out.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No. I'm not gonna stay long. Bob, I don't want to get married.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I've really thought about it a lot, and if you had asked me last year I'm sure I would have said yes.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Oh. Thank you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: But I'm not sure it would have been a good idea then either. I'm going through a really hard time right now and I just think that getting engaged to you or anyone would be just about the stupidest most self-destructive thing I could possibly do.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: And I really think you have to grow up.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Well, how about we fix up my personality some other time?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: OK.  I really hope we can still be friends.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Oh, yes, me too.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Bob... This is so crazy... I mean... I don't even understand why you... I don't even get it.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What do you want me to say? Everything you said about me was true, Sammy. I was just a big chickenshit jerk, and now I'm payin' the price.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Bob...!

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- I don't know...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I don't know. Sammy, I love you. I wish I could say it in a more interesting way. I just -- I love you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- I mean -- I love you too --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh shit.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I gotta go. I'm sorry --

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Where do you have to go?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm supposed to -- I gotta get Mabel back her car.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Well... I don't understand. How are we leaving things?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh God, I don't know. Call me later.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Sorry I'm so late.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, I was just about to give up on you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- maybe it would've been better if you had...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I mean -- Look, I don't mean to be unsympathetic about your domestic situation, whatever it is, but I'm just beginning to think that if people tried a little harder to stick to their commitments and started taking a little responsibility for their actions, they might end up having a lot less trouble generally. That's all.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Hey, that's what I've been trying to tell you guys at the bank.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I really don't think I can do this anymore.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: OK.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: This is incredible.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Mmmm.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That is not what I mean.

Dialogue: Maybe we should call first.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well -- We're right here.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: There he is.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: His last name is Kolinski?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah. Ring the bell.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hi. We're looking for Rudy?

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: Who should I say is calling?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: An old friend.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: He says an old friend!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey, Rudy.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hi, I'm Terry.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: And this is Rudy.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: You don't say.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Rudy, meet Rudy.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: I'll just be in the kitchen.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Nice to meet you.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK if we come in for a minute?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What do you mean what am I doin' --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well we just wanna --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: All right, all right.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I just wanted the kid to see you --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Man, you are really --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I just wanna --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You know what, man? You're still a fuckin' asshole.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: Get your fuckin' hands off him...!

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: They just showed up! We never seen them before...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I just came down here to talk to the guy and all of a sudden he starts shovin' me!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You're a lyin' fuckin' piece of shit.

Speaker: janie
Dialogue: We have a right to protect ourselves. What else do you need to know?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: This is such bullshit. He started the whole thing and you're arresting me?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What time is it?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh my gosh.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Hey, you know, Nancy's gonna be gone for the rest of the week...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You know... Brian...

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I don't want to... I mean, couldn't we just... I mean, could we give it a rest?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Um -- Yeah. Sure. If you want to.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I mean... I just think... I don't know: We had a great little fling. You know? Let's not push it.  I mean, is that OK? I just --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah. Sure. OK. You're right.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: So are we still friends?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Mm hm. Sure.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: All right. Good...!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Around two o'clock this afternoon... Yeah, a ninety three Toyota Tercel. New York plates V127AC... Please.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Thanks for coming over. I just want to have a car handy just in case.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- what about other towns?... Yes! Yes! I called the highway patrol four times... Well what am I supposed to do all night?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Anyone hear from Sammy this morning?

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: I didn't.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Uh huh. Well, if anyone ever hears from her ever again, will you let me know?

Speaker: mabel
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: It's gonna be all right... We got on the phone and talked to Rudy Sr. a little bit and he's calmed down, just wants to forget about the whole thing...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Darryl, I really appreciate this...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah, it's Brian.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Brian --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: What the hell happened to you today, lady?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: You're fired!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: GOOD!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Is there anything you want to ask me, about your father?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Oh, that wasn't my father.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: That wasn't him. I heard him tell the cops.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: No -- Rudy -- that was him. But that was him. I wish it wasn't, but it was.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: No it wasn't.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy. Yes it was. Your father's name is Rudy Kolinski. He lives in Auburn...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Could you turn that off for a minute please?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You don't have to say anything, Sammy.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I want you to leave.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I mean I don't think you should live here anymore. I don't think you know how to behave around an eight-year- old and I don't know how to make you stop, so I think you shouldn't live here. I don't know what else to say.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know how to behave around an eight-year-old?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: That's right --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I think you don't know how to behave around an eight-year-old.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Are you out of your MIND!?!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Now you just listen to me. I may not be the greatest mother in the world, but I'm doing the best I know how. And he doesn't need you to rub his face in shit because you think it's good for him. He's going to find out the world is a horrible place and that people suck soon enough, and without any help from you. Believe me!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I think you should get your own place. I thought, if you want, you could -- I'll be glad to help you out financially --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: What do you mean, Get my own place?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I mean I --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: You mean in Scottsville?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Why would I do that? Why don't I just leave, period?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well... If that's what you want to do, that's fine. But that's not what I'm saying. You are a very important person to Rudy, and you are the most important person to me. But I'm saying that I can't take any more of this --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- I thought -- maybe you could sell your half of the house to me, and I could pay you whatever it is over a certain amount of time, and that way --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No, you know what? I'll just go.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- that's not what I'm saying.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know. I just want to get out of this town. And if you've got any sense when you get old enough you'll get out of here too. Your Mom's gonna live in this town for the rest of her life, and you know why? Because she thinks she has to. Don't ask me why, but that's the truth. She thinks there's all these things she has to do, but you want to know one thing about your Mom? She's a bigger fuck- up than I ever was. I mean, I know I messed up. You think I enjoy getting thrown in jail because I wanted you to face that prick your Dad like a little man and see what kind of a guy he is? I know I got a little carried away, and I lost my temper just a little bit -- which is not the end of the world either, by the way, just for future reference --And now she's kickin' me out of my own house because -- you know, because I fucked up a little bit. Which I totally admit. I was like -- totally ready to admit that.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I could go with you.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well, thanks, man. But I, uh, I can't really take care of you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Is that for you?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I'm just gonna stay at Ray's till I take off.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You don't have to do that.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah. Well, that's what I wanna do, so --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well but -- Are you gonna come back to say good-bye?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No -- I'm just gonna take off. I'll see you later.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Look. I know you're upset about Uncle Terry leaving, and so am I. But he's just not in control of himself, and I don't want him hurting your feelings anymore -- or mine. And you may not like it, but that's how it's gotta be. OK?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I don't care.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You don't care. I don't care either.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well... I'm sorry you're havin' all this trouble...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: But you made a pretty good speech to me yesterday about people sticking to their commitments...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Yeah...?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well... you made a commitment to this bank, Sammy. To this job.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I know I'd --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: And to working things out with this tough new son of a bitch boss of yours. And whatever might have passed between us after hours doesn't mean you just walk away from that commitment -- yeah, even when you have a legitimate family emergency.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm really sorry I didn't --

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Which is why I think in the calm cold light of day, we should both think real hard about whether or not you really want to continue on here at Merchants National Trust.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You're not serious.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: ...you're not happy, I'm not happy, it's not good for you and it sure as heck isn't good for the bank.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You know you're the worst manager we've ever had?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Come on, Sammy...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: By far the worst.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: ...I don't wanna trade insults with you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I don't want to be fired, Brian. I've been working here for seven years.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: And if I were you I'd be a little nervous about firing an employee I just had an affair with. OK?

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: That's -- Don't threaten me, Sammy: I'm not threatening you. I -- It's just an area I think we should explore.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I'm not thr -- You explore it. I'm going back to work.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh, and I have to pick up Rudy today because there's no one else to do it. But I'll find someone as soon as I have time.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: Yeah. Fine. Why don't you just take over the whole bank?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I called where Uncle Terry said he was gonna stay, and there was no answer, so I don't know if he's still in town or not.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy? Are you not speaking to me?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, I'm sorry you're so mad at me, but I only did what I thought I had to do, and I hope you don't stay mad at me for the rest of your life.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Rudy, that's too much.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You gotta cut this out!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What did I do?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You don't know what you're talking about! There was nothing else I could do! I can't explain it better than that, but you can't go on like this because you don't know anything about it and you don't know what you're doing!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: OK, I'm sorry!

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I don't want you to be sorry, I just want you to STOP IT!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I will! I will! I'm stopping, I'm sorry.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: See? I'm stopping! I'm not doing it. See? I'm not.

Dialogue: Ray's house.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I didn't know if you left yet.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No -- I'm leavin' tomorrow.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- What time?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: There's a bus at nine.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well -- Can I -- I'd like to see you before you go. I mean, can I give you a lift? Or do you want to have breakfast or anything? And I think Rudy would really like to say good- bye.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah -- I don't know... I mean --

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Terry, you can't just leave like this. I --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: All right, all right. I'll come by in the morning.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: All right -- But just -- We have to be out of the house by eight, so -- I don't want to tell Rudy you're coming unless you really think you can make it --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah -- No -- I'll be there.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You should get your sneakers on.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Sweetie, I'm sorry, we have to go.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Why can't I miss school one day?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey, how's it goin', man?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sorry I'm late.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: So Rudy... If I write you a letter, will you write me back?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: OK, well, that's gonna be pretty nice for you, because I write a pretty Goddamn interesting letter.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Yeah, we'll see.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: All right. Well, say good-bye.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Do you need some cash for the bus?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No, I got a few bucks... Aren't you gonna be late for work?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh -- Yeah. That's OK.  Terry, I don't even know where you're going.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Oh, well, I didn't really have a concrete plan yet. I have to go back to Worcester and get my stuff...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Oh, are you gonna try to see that girl?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Well... Yeah... You know... Thought maybe I'd try to show my face... Let her brother have a crack at me...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: ...I don't want anyone to have a crack at you.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I'm just kidding. I just thought... Just thought I'd check up on her...  Anyway, after that, I don't really know. I've been thinking about Alaska a lot. I still got some friends out there. I don't really know. Anyway, I'll write you.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: You will?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Sure, Sammy. Of course I will. You know that.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: What is gonna happen to you?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Nothing too bad... But I gotta tell you, I know things didn't work out too well this time...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Well, Terry --

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: ...but it's always really good to know that wherever I am, whatever stupid shit I'm doing, you're back at my home, rooting for me.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I do root for you.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Come on, Sammy. Everything's gonna be all right... Comparatively... And I'll be back this way...

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: I feel like I'm never gonna see you again...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Of course you will, Sammy. You never have to worry about that.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Please don't go till you know where you're going. Please...!

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I do know where I'm going. I'm going to Worcester and I'm gonna try to see that girl. And then depending on what happens there, I thought I'd try to see if there's any work for me out West. And if there is, I'm gonna head out there for the summer and try to make some money. And if there isn't, I'll figure something else out. Maybe I'll stay around the East. I don't know... I really liked it in Alaska. It was really beautiful. You just -- It made me feel good. And before things got so messed up I was doin' pretty well out there. Seriously. But I couldn't stay here long, Sammy: I don't want to live here. But I'm gonna stay in touch. And I'll be back. 'Cause I want to see you and I want to see Rudy. I'll come home for Christmas. How about that? We'll have Christmas together.  Come on, Sammy. You can trust me...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Come on, Sammy... Look at me... Look at me...

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Hey, Sammy... Remember when we were kids, remember what we always used to say to each other . . .?  Remember when we were kids?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Of course I do...!
